div.p:
Not having heard anything
more respecting the intended Publication I am not
aware whether the design has been abandon'd, or
whether its accomplishment may be so far advanced
as to render the annex'd too late for insertion.
If in time, and worth using, they are heartily
at thy Service. I only wish I could have sent
thee somewhat worthier of thy acceptance, but if
these serve to show that I wish well to
thy efforts, & the object they have in view
one end is answered.

In the first of the
annexed trifles I have endeavor'd briefly
to express some of those better feelings which
I cannot but think the common dictates of Nature must
excite in the unfortunate Slave Mother, in reference to
her equally miserable Child. But as I believe instances
occur, would they were more frequent, in which through
the labours of Missionaries &c the Consolations of the Gospel
are opened to those injured & devoted Beings, I have en-
deavour'd in the second short article to embody some of
the thoughts & feelings of a Converted Negro –– still, I hope, without
compromise of the principle. Surely the sentiment contained
in the concluding Verse must occur to such an one –– for in
my view deplorable as is the Bondage of the unhappy Negro
the Slavery of the Enslaver, the hopeless yoke of which
he is the bigoted Victim, implies a thraldom yet not more
dreadful ––

lg.l: Sleep, my child! and might the prayer
Of thy Mother's dark despair
Be accepted for thy sake,––
'Twere that thou no more shouldst wake,
Though a Mother's Love be mine,
And a Daughter's fondness thine,
Yet for thee A Parent's breath
Craves the boon of early death.
Worse to live a helpless Slave,
Than to fill an early grave;
Better far the silent tomb,
Than the Captive's hopeless doom.
White Man's cruelty and lust
Cannot harm the lifeless dust;
Powerless the Oppressor's rod
Brandish'd o'er a senseless clod.
Ruthless lash, and galling chain,
Ceaseless tasks -– perform'd with pain,
Nights of sorrow, days of toil--
These have made my life their spoil.
Such, with Life, must be thy Lot;
Dying –– thou shalt know them not; ––
O be thine, all fetters breaking,
Sleep that knows on earth no waking!

div.head: A Christian Negro's thanks, and Prayer.

lg.l: O Father of the human race!
The white, the black, the bond, the free;––
Thanks for thy Gift of heavenly Grace,
Vouchsaf'd, through Jesus Christ, to me.
This, 'mid Oppression's every wrong,
Has borne my sinking spirit up;
Made sorrow joyful, -- weakness strong,
And sweetened Slavery's bitter cup.
Hath not A Saviour's dying hour
Made e'en the yoke of thraldom light?
Hath not Thy Holy Spirit's power
Made bondage freedom; -- darkness bright?
Thanks, then, O Father! for the gift,
Which through Thy Gospel Thou hast given;
Which thus from bonds and earth can lift
The Soul to liberty and Heaven.
But not the less I mourn their shame,
Who, mindless of Thy gracious Will,
Call on A Father's -- Saviour's Name,
Yet keep their Brethren Bondsmen still!
Forgive them, Lord! for Jesus' sake;
And since The Slave Thou hast unbound,--
The chains which bind The Oppressor -- break,
And be Thy Love's last triumph crowned!
